items.description: Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water
items.message: River and lake levels remain high on the Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water due to recent rainfall. Today, Thursday 03/11/2022, is forecast to be largely dry, and the lake level at the Lodore gauge has levelled off. However the lake will remain high for at least the next few days, with further rain forecast over the coming weekend. Flooding is affecting locations near these rivers and the lake, with low lying land most affected, particularly around the Upper Derwent from Seathwaite to Derwent Water. We will continue to monitor levels closely. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 04/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Rivers Brathay, Rothay and Winster

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Brathay, River Rothay, River Winster

items.message:
There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain.
The forecast is for no further significant rainfall until Sunday.
River levels will start to fall, but still remain quite high in some locations and a Flood Alert remains in force for the wider area.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert/warning if necessary.
Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

items.description: North Sea coast at Bridlington
items.message: No further flood impacts are expected in this area, and the flood alert has been removed for the North Sea Coast at Bridlington this morning, Thursday 03/11/22. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert/warning if necessary. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

items.description: Upper River Wey
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels remain high on the Upper Wey at Godalming as a result of persistent heavy rainfall last night. Therefore, flooding of low-lying roads, footpaths and farmland is still expected. 
Light showers are expected over the coming days, but we expect levels on the river to drop overnight and remain below flood alert.
We will continue to monitor the situation and will update this message tomorrow morning, 04/11/22 or if the situation changes.

items.description: River Stour and Smestow Brook in the Black Country and South Staffordshire
River Pinn and Woodridings Stream
items.message:
River levels are high but steady on the River Pinn and Woodridings Stream as a result of persistent heavy rainfall on Wednesday 2nd and Thursday 3rd November 2022. The risk of flooding to roads and low-lying land is now reducing but river levels remain high. 

Further light rainfall is forecast this evening, Thursday 3rd November 2022 but we do not expect river levels to rise again as a result. We expect river levels to remain high overnight until tomorrow morning, Friday 4th November. 

We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages and clearing debris from structures. 

Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses as there may still be standing water in some locations. 
This message will be updated by 9am on Friday 4th November, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Chertsey Bourne

floodArea.county: Bracknell Forest, Surrey, Windsor and Maidenhead

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels remain high on the Chertsey Bourne as a result of persistent heavy rainfall overnight. Therefore, flooding of low-lying roads and farmland is expected this evening 03/11/22, especially in the Free Prae Road area. 
Tonight, and tomorrow are relatively dry with some isolated showers. We expect river to fall overnight and into the morning.
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 
This message will be updated tomorrow morning 04/11/22, or if the situation changes.

items.description: River Trent in Derbyshire
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. No further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.

items.description: South East Somerset Rivers, Upper Reaches

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Yeo, River Cam, River Wriggle, Barwick Stream, West Coker Stream

items.message: Water levels have risen at the Sherborne Lake river gauge as a result of the recent heavy rainfall. Consequently, there remains a low risk of flooding to low-lying land and roads. Locations most vulnerable to flooding are the Sparkford to Weston Bampfylde road and Deep Ford Lane, Chetnole. Further rainfall is forecast overnight so we expect river levels to remain high. Our incident response staff are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low-lying footpaths and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers which may be flooded; refer to local authority website for local road closures. This message will be updated by 11:00 on Friday, 4/11/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Severn Vyrnwy confluence
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have remained below the flood risk threshold as less rain was received than forecast.      
We continue to monitor the situation.

items.message:
The flood forecast has changed. As a result, there is currently not a risk of flooding in the area.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.
Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths.

items.message:
River levels are falling this morning on 03/03/2022.
We will continue to monitor levels closely.

items.description: River Uck
items.message: The River Uck is high and rising. 60mm of rain has been recorded at Buxted on Thursday morning, which is more than half a month's rainfall in only a few hours. Flood Warnings are in force in Buxted and Isfield, and river levels are very high in Uckfield. Flooding will continue to affect riverside properties through Buxted, near the White Hart pub. As well as areas around Hempstead Mill on Hempstead Lane, Uckfield and near The Roller Mill, Mill Lane, River Way, Bridge Cottage & Bell Walk Uckfield. In Isfield flooding will affect locations at Isfield Mill and Isfield Bridge. Rain is now clearing to the east, leaving a largely dry afternoon. River levels should begin to fall from 14:00 03/11/2022 in Buxted and 20:00 in Isfield, but will remain higher than normal until Friday. Please take proactive action to help reduce the impact of flooding. Please keep flood protection products installed, if you have them. We have closed our flood gate in Uckfield town centre to reduce flood risk. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 22:00 on 03/11/2022.

items.description: Silk Stream and the Deans, Edgware, Dollis, Mutton and Wealdstone Brooks

floodArea.riverOrSea: Silk Stream, Dollis Brook, Deans Brook, Edgware Brook, Mutton Brook, Wealdstone Brook

items.message:
River levels in the Hendon, Wembley, Harrow, Wealdstone, Edgware and Stanmore areas have now fallen following heavy rainfall in the early hours of this morning, Thursday 3rd November 2022. 

We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. Further light rainfall is forecast this evening, and into tomorrow morning, Friday 4th November but we do not expect any further flooding. 

We recommend that you avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses as there may still be standing water in some locations. 

Our incident response staff are monitoring the situation and clearing trash screens where necessary. We recommend that you remain aware of the forecast for the next 5 days. There is currently more heavy rain forecast on Sunday 6th November.

items.message:
River levels have risen as a result of heavy rainfall. Flooding of roads and low lying land is expected between 09:30 and 21:00 today, 3 November 2022. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads around Forest Row, Ashurst, Hartfield and Penshurst and low lying land and roads close to the rivers, particularly on and around Balls Green and Ashurst.   
We expect river levels to remain high until 21:00 today, 3 November 2022. 

We are continuing to monitor the situation and our incident response staff are out on the ground checking and clearing any blockages and debris from rivers.

items.message: River levels have risen as a result of heavy and persistent rainfall overnight and during the morning of Thursday. Flooding of roads and low lying land is expected today, 03/11/2022 and through until Friday. Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours, and we expect river levels to remain high throughout today and into Friday 04/11/2022. We are closely monitoring the situation and our incident response staff are clearing trash screens across the catchment. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 20:00 on 03/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Biss catchment
items.message:
River levels have risen at the Trowbridge Paxcroft river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible this morning and afternoon 03/11/22.  We believe there is a possibility of flooding for Heather Shaw Road and West Ashton Road on the Paxcroft Brook and riverside properties at Southwick, Lambrok Close, Berkeley Road, Acacia Crescent and Albion Drive on the Lambrok Stream. River levels have risen overnight   and have reacted  to  the heavy persistent rain   Flood water could be deep and fast flowing, and therefore pose a risk to life.
Further showery  rainfall is forecast over the next  12 hours.  We expect river levels to remain high until over the next few days and react to  further rainfall..
We are closely monitoring the situation.   Our incident response staff are clearing weed screens.  
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers which may be flooded and refer to local authority website for local road closures.  
This message will be updated Thursday  afternoon 03/11/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Rivers on the Isle of Sheppey
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the level expected to cause flooding. Our incident response staff are are out on the ground checking and clearing any blockages and debris from on the Scrapsgate Drain. 
We will continue to monitor the river levels and re-issue this alert if necessary.

items.description: Buxted
items.message: River levels in Buxted are still high, but are now slowly falling, following Thursday morning's heavy rain. Thursday afternoon (03/11/2022) should remain largely dry, but flooding will continue to affect fields, rural roads and gardens throughout Thursday evening, including riverside properties near the White Hart pub in Buxted and around Hempstead Mill on Hempstead Lane, Uckfield. There is uncertainty in the forecast but there is a possibility of some heavy showers passing through Sussex on Thursday evening, which could cause river levels to rise again. Riverside properties in Buxted are encouraged to keep their flood protection products installed, if you have them. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 11:00 on 04/11/2022.

items.description: River Teise area from Lamberhurst to Goudhurst
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
River levels have risen as a result of heavy rainfall.  Flooding of roads and low lying land is expected between 9:00 and 13:00 on Thursday 3 November 2022. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads along the River Teise particularly in Lamberhurst.   

Further heavy rainfall is forecast over this morning, Thursday 3 November 2022. We are continuing to monitor the situation and our incident response staff are out on the ground checking and clearing any blockages and debris from rivers. This message will be updated by 18:00, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Adur East Branch
items.message: The River Adur is high and rising following Thursday morning's heavy rain. From 15:30 on Thursday (03/11/2022), flooding will affect the A281 at Mock Bridge, near Shermanbury. As well as extensive water in fields, flooding will also affect properties near Mock Bridge and their gardens. Rain is now clearing to the east, leaving a largely dry afternoon. The river should begin to fall by 21:00 on Thursday (03/11/2022) but will be higher than normal until Friday (04/11/2022). Flood impacts should begin to slowly ease when river levels start to fall. There is a chance further rain on Thursday evening could cause river levels to rise again. Some roads, including the A281 at Mock Bridge, may become impassable. Please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 11:00 on 04/11/2022.

items.description: Eastern Yar
items.message: Water levels in the Eastern Yar are high and rising. In the last 12 hours, over 30mm of rain has been recorded at Knighton. A significant amount in a short time. From 11:00, water will be ponded on low lying land adjacent to the river throughout the river valley. At Langbridge and Alverstone, the river will be close to the top of the riverbank. Property flooding is not currently expected. Flooding of Golf Links Road and Moreton Common Road, Sandown may occur from 20:00 03/11/2022. Ditches around Fort Holiday Park will struggle to drain. Showers are forecast for today (03/11/2022). At Alverstone, the river will continue rising until approximately 14:00 this afternoon (03/11/2022). At Sandown, levels will not peak until tomorrow morning (04/11/2022). Neap tides are expected over the next 2 days, and the river will have little opportunity to drain to sea. We continue to monitor the forecast and will ensure the river remains free of reported blockages. Please ensure products used to protect gardens and property from flooding are operating. Flood Alert will be updated at 19:00 03/11/2022.

items.description: River Bourne from Hadlow to East Peckham
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
River levels have risen as a result of heavy rainfall. Flooding of roads and low lying land is expected imminently until 13:00 on Thursday 3 November 2022. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads along the River Bourne at Hadlow and Little Mill.   

Further rainfall is forecast over this morning, 3 November 2022. We are continuing to monitor the situation and our incident response staff are out on the ground checking and clearing any blockages and debris from the rivers. 
  
This message will be updated by 18:00 or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Blackwater and The Cove Brook
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels remain high on the River Blackwater as a result of persistent heavy rainfall last night. Therefore, flooding of low-lying roads, footpaths and farmland is expected this evening today, especially in the Camberley area. 
Tonight, and tomorrow will be relatively dry, with a few light showers, therefore levels should start to fall.
We are closely monitoring the situation. 
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and avoid contact with flood water. 
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 04/11/22, or if the situation changes.

items.description: Upper Ouse
items.message: The River Ouse is high and rising. Half a month's rainfall (50mm) has been recorded at Ardingly on Thursday morning. From 11:00 on 03/11/2022 flooding could affect the Anchor Inn and areas of Barcombe Mills. Barcombe Mills Road could be affected by flood water. Minor flood impacts could affect fields, rural roads, gardens near Freshfield Mill Farm on Sloop Lane and Bridge Cottage, Sheffield Park. Roads at Fletching Mill Bridge and Sharpsbridge will likely also be affected. Rain is forecast to ease by midday Thursday 03/11/2022. However, in Barcombe, the river might not begin to fall until 21:00 on 03/11/2022 and will remain higher than normal until Friday afternoon. Near the top of the River Ouse, near Ardingly and Lindfield Bridge on the B2028, river levels should begin to fall earlier - by Thursday afternoon. Please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding, including Barcombe Mills Road. We are operating our structures at Pimms Lock and Barcombe to help keep the river flowing freely and reduce flood risk. We will update this message by 19:00 on 03/11/2022.

items.description: The upper Stour and surrounding tributaries
items.message: Levels are now well below the flood risk thresholds. The forecast is for no significant rainfall overnight into tomorrow, but further rain is expected at the weekend. There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

items.description: River Teise and Lesser Teise area from Horsmonden to Yalding
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
River levels have risen as a result of heavy rainfall. Flooding of roads and low lying land is expected to occur from 10am on Thursday 3 November 2022 and may continue for the rest of the day. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads close to river in and around Collier Street. Flooding of property is not expected at this stage.  

Further rainfall is forecast over this morning, Thursday 3 November 2022. We are continuing to monitor the situation and our incident response staff are out on the ground checking and clearing any blockages and debris from the rivers. 

This message will be updated by 18:00 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Bumpstead Brook through Steeple Bumpstead to New England
items.message: River levels are now steadily falling. A Flood Alert remains in force for the wider area. The forecast is for further unsettled weather over the next few days. There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

items.description: Cuckmere River
items.message: The Cuckmere River is high and rising, following 25mm of rain recorded at Cowbeech Thursday morning. From 11:30 03/11/2022 minor flood impacts could affect fields, rural roads, gardens and approach properties on Mill Lane, Hellingly, Grove Hill near Grovebridge Farm and Hammer Lane near Cowbeech. From 15:00 03/11/2022 minor flood impacts could also affect Station Road, Church Lane and Church Road, Hellingly, and gardens of properties on those roads. From 21:00 03/11/2022 minor flood impacts could also affect North Street, Willows Car Park, River Lane, The Old Clergy House and Deans Place Hotel, Alfriston. Only another 5mm of rain is forecast before clearing to leave Thursday afternoon largely dry. The river should begin to fall by 16:00 on Mill Lane, Hellingly, but potentially not until late Thursday evening near Church Road Hellingly and Friday afternoon in Alfriston. Please plan to avoid driving through routes susceptible to flooding, including the locations within this message. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 20:00 03/11/2022.

Further rainfall is forecast to continue today, 3 November 2022. 

We are continuing to monitor the situation and our incident response staff are out on the ground checking and clearing any blockages and debris from rivers. This message will be updated by 18:00, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Isfield
items.message: The River Uck is high and rising. More than half a month's rain (60mm) has been recorded at Buxted during Thursday morning, which is a lot in a short space of time. From 11:30 03/11/2022 flooding will affect properties at Isfield Mill and Isfield Bridge as well as fields, rural roads and gardens. Only another 5mm of rain is forecast, before clearing to leave Thursday afternoon largely dry. The river should begin to fall by 21:00 03/11/2022, but will be higher than normal until Friday. There is a chance further rain Thursday evening could cause river levels to rise again. Please take proactive action to help reduce the impact of flooding. Flood protection products are recommended to be installed in Isfield, if you have them. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 21:00 03/11/2022.

items.description: Mock Bridge, near Shermanbury on the River Adur
items.message: The River Adur is high and rising. In the last 12 hours, more than half a month's rain (46mm) has been recorded at Cowfold, which is a lot in a short period of time. From 15:30 on Thursday (03/11/2022), flooding will affect the A281 at Mock Bridge, near Shermanbury. As well as extensive water in fields, flooding will also affect properties near Mock Bridge and their gardens. Rain is now clearing to the east, leaving a largely dry afternoon. The river should begin to fall by 21:00 on 03/11/2022 but will be higher than normal until Friday (04/11/2022). Flood impacts should begin to slowly ease when river levels start to fall. There is a chance further rain on Thursday evening could cause river levels to rise again. Some roads, including the A281 at Mock Bridge, may become impassable. Please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 21:00 on 03/11/2022.

items.description: The Rivers Wid and Can
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to low-lying land, roads and riverside areas is likely over the next few hours and into tomorrow, Thursday, and into Friday 4th November. The River Wid is rising steadily in response to recent heavy rainfall. Areas most at risk are low-lying roads and riverside areas, including Lordship Lane and Cow Watering Lane around Writtle College. Further outbreaks of rain are expected today and overnight, clearing the area by tomorrow morning. The forecast is for further unsettled spells over the next few days. Take care on riverside footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and will update this message by 9pm tomorrow, Friday 4th November.

items.description: The River Bure, Spixworth Beck and surrounding Becks
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to low-lying land, roads and riverside areas is likely over the next few hours and into tomorrow, Thursday, and into Friday 4th November. Spixworth Beck is rising steadily in response to recent heavy rainfall. Areas most at risk are low-lying roads and riverside areas between Horsford and Crostwick on the Spixworth Beck, and Corpusty, Saxthorpe, Itteringham, Ingworth,  Aylsham and Burgh-next-Aylsham on the Bure. Further outbreaks of rain are expected today and overnight, clearing the area by tomorrow morning. The forecast is for further unsettled spells over the next few days. Take care on riverside footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and will update this message by 9pm tomorrow, Friday 4th November.

items.description: Lower River Medway
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
The River Medway has risen as a result of heavy rainfall in Kent during Thursday 3 November 2022.  Localised flooding in the vicinity of the river is expected to occur between 4pm on Thursday 3 November 2022, and 10am on Friday 4 November.  

We expect flooding to affect low lying land along the River Medway particularly footpaths and riverside areas in Yalding, Wateringbury, Teston, East Farleigh and Maidstone.   

We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are liaising with emergency services and our partners and ensuring our structures are operating correctly.  
  
This message will be updated in 8 hours, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The tidal River Waveney from Ellingham to Breydon Water
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely in the early hours of the morning on Friday 4th November, from 4am to 7am. River levels will gradually rise overnight following this evening's tide, and remain high through the early morning tide. This is due to a natural tide-locking effect and the heavy rainfall in the last 24 hours draining through the River Waveney. We expect to see high water levels at Beccles Quay. We are not currently expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate. We will update this message by 9am tomorrow, Friday 4th November.

items.description: The tidal River Yare from Thorpe St Andrew to Breydon Water
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely in the early hours of the morning on Friday 4th November from 4am to 7am. River levels will gradually rise overnight following this evening's tide, and remain high through the early morning tide. This is due to a natural tide-locking effect, and the heavy rainfall in the last 24 hours draining through the River Yare. We expect to see high water levels in Brundall and Reedham riverside areas. We are not currently expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate. We will update this message by 9am tomorrow, Friday 4th November.

items.description: Hellingly and Horsebridge
items.message: The Bull River through Hellingly is high and rising. 50mm of rain has been measured at Vines Cross on Thursday. This is a lot in a short period of time, more than we'd normally expect over two weeks. From 18:00 03/11/2022 flooding will affect gardens and properties on Station Road, Church Lane and Church Road, Hellingly. Nearby fields and rural roads will be affected too. The Cuckmere River through Grove Hill near Grovebridge Farm and Mill Lane, Hellingly has already started to fall and conditions should improve here. There is uncertainty in the weather forecast. Although showers are possible Thursday evening, the Bull River should begin to fall in Hellingly by 20:00 03/11/2022, but not returning to normal until Friday afternoon. If heavy showers occur from 21:00 Thursday 03/11/2022, river levels could yet rise overnight. Some roads may become impassable, please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding, including Station Road, Church Lane and Church Road, Hellingly. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 10:00 04/11/2022.

items.description: Exmoor Rivers
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Barle, River Exe, River Lyn, River Mole, River Bray

items.message:
Over the last 24 hours we have had heavy rainfall over the North Devon area causing river levels to rise.  Some areas may receive an additional 30-40 mm of rain in a few hours which could lead to some flooding impacts.

Rivers in this area likely to respond quickly and flooding to low lying land and roads is possible. 

Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions. 

We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff in the area checking for and clearing blockages in this location. This message will be updated on Friday morning or earlier if the situation changes.

items.description: Barcombe Mills
items.message: The River Ouse is high and rising. 50mm of rain has been measured in Barcombe on Thursday. This is a lot in a short period of time, more than we'd normally expect over two weeks. From 17:00 03/11/2022 flooding will be extensive through fields. Barcombe Mills Road and Anchor Lane are likely to be impassable. The Anchor Inn will be affected by flooding and water could approach properties at Barcombe Mills. There is uncertainty in the weather forecast. Although showers are possible Thursday evening, the Ouse should begin to fall in Barcombe by 22:00 03/11/2022, but not returning to normal until Friday afternoon. If heavy showers occur from 21:00 Thursday 03/11/2022, river levels could rise Friday morning. Some roads may become impassable, please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding, including Barcombe Mills Road. Flood protection products are recommended to be installed in Barcombe, if you have them. We are operating our structures in Barcombe to help keep the river flowing freely and reduce flood risk. We will update this message by 10:00 04/11/2022.

Rivers in this area likely to respond quickly and flooding to low lying land and roads is possible. 

Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions. 

We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff in the area checking for and clearing blockages in this location. This message will be updated on Friday morning or earlier if the situation changes.
